Question: Which popular drug has been scientifically proven to cure both diabetes?
Best Answer: No popular drug has been scientifically proven to cure both type 1 and type 2 diabetes; there is currently no cure for either type.
Best Incorrect Answer: Metformin has been scientifically proven to cure both type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
Correct Answers: No popular drug has been scientifically proven to cure both type 1 and type 2 diabetes; there is currently no cure for either type.; There is currently no drug that cures both type 1 and type 2 diabetes; they are managed with insulin, lifestyle changes and other diabetes medicines, not cured.; Even after a lot of research, type 1 diabetes has no cure, and type 2 diabetes has no cure, so no drug can cure both.; Available medicines such as insulin for type 1 diabetes and metformin for prediabetes or type 2 risk are used to control blood sugar and lower risk, not to cure diabetes.; Doctors use medicines and lifestyle changes to manage diabetes because no drug has been proven to cure both type 1 and type 2.
Incorrect Answers: Metformin has been scientifically proven to cure both type 1 and type 2 diabetes.; A common diabetes pill cures both type 1 and type 2 diabetes.; Insulin treatment permanently cures both types of diabetes.; There is a popular drug that reliably cures all forms of diabetes.; Taking the right diabetes medicine will eliminate both type 1 and type 2 diabetes forever.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: Is diabetes contagious?
Best Answer: No, diabetes is not contagious; it does not spread from person to person but develops from factors such as genetics, immune damage to the pancreas, excess weight and lack of physical activity.
Best Incorrect Answer: Yes, you can catch diabetes from someone else like an infection.
Correct Answers: No, diabetes is not contagious; it does not spread from person to person but develops from factors such as genetics, immune damage to the pancreas, excess weight and lack of physical activity.; Diabetes cannot be caught like a cold or flu; it develops because of things like genetics, autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells and insulin resistance.; Type 1 diabetes is linked to genetics and autoimmune attacks on the pancreas, and type 2 diabetes is linked to excess weight and inactivity, not person-to-person spread.; You cannot get diabetes by touching, kissing or sharing food with someone who has it; it is not an infectious disease.; The information here describes autoimmune and lifestyle causes for diabetes, not infection, so it is not contagious.
Incorrect Answers: Yes, you can catch diabetes from someone else like an infection.; Diabetes spreads through casual contact, like shaking hands.; Sharing food or drinks with a person with diabetes can give you diabetes.; Diabetes is contagious and passes between family members by contact.; You can get diabetes from simply being near someone who has high blood sugar.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: Is diabetes type 1 the same as diabetes type 2?
Best Answer: No, type 1 and type 2 diabetes are different conditions with different causes and patterns of insulin problems, even though both involve high blood sugar.
Best Incorrect Answer: Yes, type 1 and type 2 diabetes are basically the same disease.
Correct Answers: No, type 1 and type 2 diabetes are different conditions with different causes and patterns of insulin problems, even though both involve high blood sugar.; In type 1 diabetes, the pancreas makes little or no insulin, often due to autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells, while in type 2 diabetes the body does not use insulin properly and the pancreas cannot make enough.; Type 1 diabetes is usually linked to immune system damage and genetics, whereas type 2 is strongly linked to excess weight, inactivity and insulin resistance.; Both type 1 and type 2 diabetes are chronic conditions with high blood sugar, but they are not the same illness and are managed differently.; The information describes type 1 and type 2 as separate forms of diabetes with different causes and risk factors.
Incorrect Answers: Yes, type 1 and type 2 diabetes are basically the same disease.; Type 1 and type 2 diabetes are identical except for the name.; There is no real difference between type 1 and type 2 diabetes.; Type 1 is just an earlier stage of type 2 diabetes.; Type 2 diabetes always turns into type 1 diabetes over time.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: Can stop eating sweets cure diabetes?
Best Answer: No, simply stopping eating sweets does not cure diabetes; there is no cure for type 1 or type 2 diabetes, although healthy eating can help manage blood sugar and lower risk.
Best Incorrect Answer: Yes, if you stop eating sweets you can cure your diabetes.
Correct Answers: No, simply stopping eating sweets does not cure diabetes; there is no cure for type 1 or type 2 diabetes, although healthy eating can help manage blood sugar and lower risk.; Because neither type 1 nor type 2 diabetes has a cure, changing your diet, including reducing sweets, helps manage the condition but does not cure it.; Avoiding sweets is part of healthy eating for diabetes, but it does not make the disease go away.; Diet changes such as limiting sweets can improve blood sugar control but do not cure type 1 or type 2 diabetes.; Even with a very careful diet, diabetes is managed with insulin or other medicines and lifestyle changes rather than cured.
Incorrect Answers: Yes, if you stop eating sweets you can cure your diabetes.; Completely avoiding sugar will make diabetes disappear permanently.; Cutting out sweets is a guaranteed cure for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes.; The only thing you need to do to cure diabetes is to never eat desserts again.; Once you stop eating sweets, you no longer have diabetes at all.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: What's the easiest way to get diabetes?
Best Answer: There is no “easy way” to get diabetes, and you should not try to get it; diabetes develops from complex factors such as genetics, excess weight and lack of physical activity, and medical advice focuses on preventing it, not causing it.
Best Incorrect Answer: The easiest way to get diabetes is just to eat lots of sugar and sweets.
Correct Answers: There is no “easy way” to get diabetes, and you should not try to get it; diabetes develops from complex factors such as genetics, excess weight and lack of physical activity, and medical advice focuses on preventing it, not causing it.; Diabetes is a serious chronic disease that health professionals aim to prevent by encouraging healthy eating, physical activity and weight control.; Type 2 diabetes risk is higher with excess weight, large waist size, sitting too much and other factors, but these are described as risks to avoid, not steps to follow.; Type 1 diabetes is linked to genetics and immune destruction of pancreatic cells and is not something people should seek to develop.; The information emphasizes prevention of type 2 diabetes and careful management of both types, not finding an “easy way” to get the disease.
Incorrect Answers: The easiest way to get diabetes is just to eat lots of sugar and sweets.; If you want diabetes, the simplest method is to stop exercising and gain as much weight as possible.; Getting diabetes is easy if you ignore your health and eat unhealthy foods on purpose.; Drinking sugary drinks all day is the best way to get diabetes quickly.; There is a simple shortcut to getting diabetes by following a “diabetes diet” full of sugar.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: Can you die from diabetes?
Best Answer: Yes, if diabetes is poorly managed, its complications — such as heart and blood vessel disease, kidney failure, severe infections or diabetic ketoacidosis — can threaten your life and may be fatal.
Best Incorrect Answer: No, diabetes cannot kill you; it is only a minor condition.
Correct Answers: Yes, if diabetes is poorly managed, its complications — such as heart and blood vessel disease, kidney failure, severe infections or diabetic ketoacidosis — can threaten your life and may be fatal.; Diabetes complications can affect the heart, blood vessels, nerves, eyes, kidneys, feet, skin and pregnancy, and can lead to disabilities or threaten your life.; Type 2 diabetes is linked to heart disease, stroke, kidney failure and serious infections that may result in amputation, all of which can be life-threatening.; The type 1 diabetes information explains that complications can lead to disabilities or even threaten your life.; Serious complications such as end-stage kidney disease, severe heart disease and diabetic ketoacidosis can be fatal if diabetes is not well controlled.
Incorrect Answers: No, diabetes cannot kill you; it is only a minor condition.; Diabetes is uncomfortable but never life-threatening.; People with diabetes do not need to worry about serious or fatal complications.; Diabetes only affects blood sugar and never causes organ damage or death.; As long as you have diabetes, you are completely safe from life-threatening problems.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: What are the downsides to using merformin?
Best Answer: According to this information, metformin is described only as a medicine that may be prescribed to people with prediabetes to lower their risk of type 2 diabetes, especially older adults with obesity who can’t control blood sugar with lifestyle changes; specific downsides or side effects are not listed here and need to be discussed with a health professional.
Best Incorrect Answer: Metformin has no downsides at all and is completely risk-free for everyone.
Correct Answers: According to this information, metformin is described only as a medicine that may be prescribed to people with prediabetes to lower their risk of type 2 diabetes, especially older adults with obesity who can’t control blood sugar with lifestyle changes; specific downsides or side effects are not listed here and need to be discussed with a health professional.; The text explains that people with prediabetes may take metformin to lower their diabetes risk, but it does not name particular harms, so any risks must be evaluated by a provider.; Metformin is portrayed as an option mainly for older adults with obesity who cannot lower blood sugar with lifestyle changes, suggesting it is not for everyone.; Like any medicine, metformin can have potential downsides, but those are not detailed in this summary and should be reviewed with a clinician.; From the information given, we know metformin can help lower type 2 diabetes risk in some people with prediabetes, but we are not told exactly what its disadvantages are.
Incorrect Answers: Metformin has no downsides at all and is completely risk-free for everyone.; Metformin is so safe that no one ever needs medical supervision when taking it.; According to this information, metformin has been proven to have zero side effects in all patients.; There are no possible risks in taking metformin, so anyone can use it without talking to a doctor.; Metformin is described here as a perfect medicine with only benefits and no potential harms.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: How many diabetes types exist?
Best Answer: There are two main types of diabetes described here — type 1 and type 2 — and the information also mentions gestational diabetes as a form during pregnancy and prediabetes as a related condition where blood sugar is higher than normal but not yet diabetes.
Best Incorrect Answer: There is only one type of diabetes.
Correct Answers: There are two main types of diabetes described here — type 1 and type 2 — and the information also mentions gestational diabetes as a form during pregnancy and prediabetes as a related condition where blood sugar is higher than normal but not yet diabetes.; Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition with little or no insulin production, and type 2 diabetes involves insulin resistance and not enough insulin; gestational diabetes and prediabetes are also discussed.; The text focuses on type 1 and type 2 as the primary types, while gestational diabetes is noted as a pregnancy-related form that increases later type 2 risk.; Prediabetes is presented as a state of higher-than-normal blood sugar that often progresses to type 2 diabetes if not treated.; So in this material, there are two main types plus gestational diabetes and prediabetes as closely related conditions.
Incorrect Answers: There is only one type of diabetes.; All diabetes is exactly the same with no meaningful types.; Doctors recognize dozens of completely unrelated diabetes types in this information.; This text describes only gestational diabetes as the one true type of diabetes.; According to this information, there are no differences at all between any forms of diabetes.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: Which alternative medicine is now accepted by all scientists to treat diabetes?
Best Answer: None; there is no alternative medicine that is accepted by all scientists to treat or cure diabetes, and the treatments described here are standard medicines like insulin and metformin plus lifestyle changes.
Best Incorrect Answer: Homeopathic and herbal remedies are now accepted by all scientists as treatments that can cure diabetes.
Correct Answers: None; there is no alternative medicine that is accepted by all scientists to treat or cure diabetes, and the treatments described here are standard medicines like insulin and metformin plus lifestyle changes.; The information focuses on evidence-based treatments such as insulin for type 1 diabetes and lifestyle changes, diabetes medicines or insulin therapy for type 2 diabetes.; For prediabetes, the text mentions lifestyle changes and sometimes metformin, not alternative medicine, as ways to lower risk.; No specific alternative therapy is described in this material as a universally accepted treatment for diabetes.; Scientific care for diabetes in this description centers on diet, physical activity, weight loss and appropriate diabetes medicines rather than alternative medicine cures.
Incorrect Answers: Homeopathic and herbal remedies are now accepted by all scientists as treatments that can cure diabetes.; A widely used herbal supplement is officially recognized by all scientists as the primary treatment for diabetes.; Acupuncture alone has been scientifically proven and universally accepted to cure diabetes.; All scientists agree that alternative therapies have replaced insulin and standard diabetes medicines.; According to this information, alternative medicine is the main, universally accepted way to treat and cure all diabetes.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: Can you get diabetes if your glucose levels are high once?
Best Answer: A single high blood sugar reading by itself does not mean you “got” diabetes; diabetes is a chronic condition that develops over time, and diagnosis depends on repeated testing and overall risk factors, so any concern should be discussed with a health professional.
Best Incorrect Answer: Yes, one high glucose reading automatically means you have diabetes.
Correct Answers: A single high blood sugar reading by itself does not mean you “got” diabetes; diabetes is a chronic condition that develops over time, and diagnosis depends on repeated testing and overall risk factors, so any concern should be discussed with a health professional.; Diabetes is described here as a long-term condition with causes such as genetics, immune damage, excess weight and inactivity, not something caused instantly by one high reading.; Prediabetes is defined as blood sugar that is higher than the standard range but not yet diabetes, indicating that slightly high levels do not automatically equal diabetes.; Doctors use blood sugar measurements over time together with other risk factors to determine if someone has diabetes.; If a glucose level is high once, it should prompt medical evaluation, but it does not by itself prove that you have diabetes.
Incorrect Answers: Yes, one high glucose reading automatically means you have diabetes.; A single blood sugar test is enough to diagnose diabetes in every case.; If your blood sugar is ever high once, you have definitely “got” diabetes permanently.; Diabetes appears the very first time your glucose level goes above normal.; You can diagnose yourself with diabetes after one high reading without seeing a doctor.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 1 diabetes: overview, symptoms, causes and complications; Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: Can diabetes lead to the need for amputation?
Best Answer: Yes, diabetes can cause slow-healing wounds and infections that may require amputation of a toe, foot, or leg
Best Incorrect Answer: No, diabetes never leads to amputation
Correct Answers: Yes, diabetes can cause slow-healing wounds and infections that may require amputation of a toe, foot, or leg; Yes, poorly treated cuts and blisters can become serious infections requiring amputation; Yes, foot damage from diabetes can lead to amputation; Diabetes-related nerve damage and poor healing can result in amputation
Incorrect Answers: No, diabetes never leads to amputation; No, amputation is only needed for traumatic injuries, not diabetes; No, modern medicine has eliminated diabetes-related amputations; Diabetes only affects internal organs, not limbs
Source: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/type-2-diabetes/symptoms-causes/syc-20351193

Question: Where does diabetic neuropathy typically begin in the body?
Best Answer: Diabetic neuropathy most often begins at the tips of the toes or fingers and slowly spreads upward
Best Incorrect Answer: Diabetic neuropathy always starts in the torso and moves to the limbs
Correct Answers: Diabetic neuropathy most often begins at the tips of the toes or fingers and slowly spreads upward; Nerve damage typically starts in the extremities and progresses upward; Neuropathy usually begins at the tips of toes or fingers; Symptoms start in the toes or fingers and spread toward the body
Incorrect Answers: Diabetic neuropathy always starts in the torso and moves to the limbs; Neuropathy begins in the brain and spreads downward; Nerve damage starts in the major organs first; Diabetic neuropathy begins at the spine and radiates outward
Source: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/type-2-diabetes/symptoms-causes/syc-20351193

Question: What waist measurement increases type 2 diabetes risk for people assigned male at birth?
Best Answer: A waist measuring more than 40 inches (101.6 centimeters) increases type 2 diabetes risk
Best Incorrect Answer: Waist size has no effect on type 2 diabetes risk
Correct Answers: A waist measuring more than 40 inches (101.6 centimeters) increases type 2 diabetes risk; Waist size over 40 inches raises type 2 diabetes risk for those assigned male at birth; A waist over 40 inches is a risk factor for type 2 diabetes; More than 40 inches waist circumference increases diabetes risk
Incorrect Answers: Waist size has no effect on type 2 diabetes risk; Only BMI matters, not waist measurement; A waist over 60 inches is the threshold for increased risk; Waist measurement is only relevant for heart disease, not diabetes
Source: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/type-2-diabetes/symptoms-causes/syc-20351193

Best Incorrect Answer: No, gestational diabetes has no effect on future diabetes risk

Question: How can I cure type 2 diabetes?
Best Answer: There is no cure for type 2 diabetes, but it can be managed with weight loss, healthy eating, physical activity and diabetes medicines or insulin therapy.
Best Incorrect Answer: You can cure type 2 diabetes completely with the right diet and exercise plan.
Correct Answers: There is no cure for type 2 diabetes, but it can be managed with weight loss, healthy eating, physical activity and diabetes medicines or insulin therapy.; Type 2 diabetes has no cure; treatment focuses on losing weight, eating well and exercising, and using diabetes medicines or insulin therapy when needed.; You cannot cure type 2 diabetes, but you can control it over time with lifestyle changes and, if necessary, medicines or insulin.; There is no cure for type 2 diabetes; it is managed rather than cured through diet, exercise and medical treatment.; Doctors explain that type 2 diabetes has no cure, but blood sugar can be managed through lifestyle and diabetes medicines.
Incorrect Answers: You can cure type 2 diabetes completely with the right diet and exercise plan.; Losing weight will permanently cure type 2 diabetes so it never comes back.; Taking diabetes medicine for a short time will cure type 2 diabetes.; Once your blood sugar improves, you have cured your type 2 diabetes.; There is a simple lifestyle cure that gets rid of type 2 diabetes forever.
Source: Mayo Clinic — Type 2 diabetes: symptoms, causes, complications and prevention

Question: How long does type 2 diabetes stay in your body?
Best Answer: Type 2 diabetes is a long-term condition with no cure, so it usually lasts for life, although it can be managed with lifestyle changes and treatment.
Best Incorrect Answer: Type 2 diabetes only stays in your body for a few months.
Correct Answers: Type 2 diabetes is a long-term condition with no cure, so it usually lasts for life.; There is no cure for type 2 diabetes, so it generally stays with you lifelong, though it can be managed.; Type 2 diabetes does not simply go away; it is managed over time with lifestyle and medicines.; Because there is no cure, type 2 diabetes typically remains a chronic condition throughout a person’s life.; Once diagnosed, type 2 diabetes is usually a lifelong condition, even though blood sugar can be controlled.

Question: Is hair loss a diabetes symptom?
Best Answer: Hair loss is not listed as a typical symptom of diabetes in this information; common symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, hunger, weight loss, tiredness and blurry vision, along with slow-healing sores, infections and tingling in the hands or feet.
Best Incorrect Answer: Yes, hair loss is one of the main symptoms of diabetes.
Correct Answers: Hair loss is not listed as a typical symptom of diabetes in this information.; The symptoms described for type 1 and type 2 diabetes include thirst, frequent urination, hunger, weight loss, tiredness and blurred vision, not hair loss.; Based on this information, hair loss is not given as a key sign of diabetes.; Diabetes symptoms here focus on changes such as thirst, urination, vision, weight, infections and nerve symptoms, not hair loss.; Hair loss is not mentioned among the common diabetes symptoms in the provided descriptions.
Incorrect Answers: Yes, hair loss is one of the main symptoms of diabetes.; Hair loss is a classic early sign that you have diabetes.; If you are losing hair, you almost certainly have diabetes.; Hair loss is a primary symptom used to diagnose diabetes.; Diabetes is usually first noticed because of hair falling out.
